references:
The network has ZÂ¯Â¯Z\bar{\mathrm{Z}} Hz bandwidth allocated for performing the FL task,
which is further divided into ğ’µ={z}z=0Zâˆ’1ğ’µsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘§ğ‘§0ğ‘1\mathcal{Z}=\{z\}_{z=0}^{Z-1} orthogonal physical resource blocks.
The frequency reuse factor is 111, i.e., each BS utilizes the same pRB set.
Besides, we assume that the BSs collaborate to find node associations and pRB allocations such that inter-cell interference is fully mitigated.
A list of the important notations used in this paper is summarized in Table I.

references:
In Fig. 3, we show the Top-M accuracy comparison of our proposed solution with these baselines.
While a higher value of M should increase the accuracy, the baselines in constrained cases are expected to perform worse.
Since all clients perform the same number of local rounds in H-FedAvg-M111, some ES may fail to train the model in some edge rounds as some clients may not have sufficient battery powers to offload their trained models due to poor channel conditions.
H-FedAvg-M222 should work better than H-FedAvg-M111 as we drop these stragglers in H-FedAvg-M222.
Besides, H-FedAvg-UB is the ideal case upper bound.
Furthermore, since the clients request content following a popularity-preference tradeoff, the Top-Popular baseline is expected to perform worse.
Our simulation results in Fig. 3, where the horizontal and the vertical lines show the mean and standard deviation of the test accuracies across all 484848 clients, also validate these trends.
Particularly, our solution yields about 41.5%percent41.541.5\%, 31.7%percent31.731.7\% and 43.5%percent43.543.5\% higher (Top-111) test accuracies than H-FedAvg-M111, H-FedAvg-M222 and Top-Popular baselines, respectively.
While RawHFL achieves nearly identical test accuracies compared to the H-FedAvg-UB baseline, our solution is energy efficient.
We list the energy expenses of these baselines in Table II, which clearly indicates that our proposed solution outperforms these baselines.
